title: If the court denies the reaffirmation agreement, can the lender still repo my car?
question: I know there were cases where the judge would not approve the reaffirmation agreement for a car, but where he/she said that the lender cannot repo because the debtor tried to reaffirm.
answers: "Always" is a too-certain word in the law, but there is a line of cases that hold as you describe. One of them is a 2006 bankruptcy case in your Northern California district (Oakland bankruptcy court) that held that very thing. You can read the court's decision at http://www.canb.uscourts.gov/files/quinteromemo.pdf .

In many jurisdictions if the debtor does everything to reaffirm the debt and the judge denies the application, AND KEEPS THE PAYMENTS CURRENT there is caselaw that states that the creditor cannot repossess the car. Contact your attorney to review the cases in your court.
Ask a local attorney. Here in Virginia, if the courts rejects the agreement, you must be current on payments and insured to avoid repossession.

If you otherwise comply with the contract you should be able to keep the vehicle. A lot of it depends on who the creditor is. Most vehicle lenders allow what is called a retain and pay with a reaffirmation.

If you keep your payments and insurance up to date, the lender will usually allow you to keep the vehicle, even if the reaffirmation agreement is denied. However, that does not mean that they are bound by that. If the judge denies the reaffirmation agreement, you should discuss your options with your attorney. I've had some clients keep making payments, and they have had no problems. I've had others who enter into a new contract with their lender after the bankruptcy, to make sure there won't be any risk.

If the reaffirmation agreement is denied, you should also check to see whether the lender will note your payment history on your credit report. Many companies (rightly or wrongly) are saying they will not report your good payment history on your credit report without a valid, approved reaffirmation agreement.
